title: 103_s1208
content: The Act is titled the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were cared for by local government before the National Park Service took over preservation duties. The Federal Government has been unable to meet the capital needs of historic sites due to financial constraints and increased responsibilities of the National Park Service. Minting a United States coin is proposed as a way to commemorate these buildings and help fund their maintenance and preservation. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 1,000,000 $1 silver coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The coins will feature the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall designs, along with inscriptions of various patriotic phrases. These coins will be legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS. The coins authorized under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility for a period of up to one year after enactment. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted. A surcharge of $7 per coin is required for all sales. Additionally, there is a general waiver of procurement regulations. SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods/services for this Act. Compliance with equal employment laws is still required. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. 50% of surcharges from coin sales go to the Treasury to reduce national debt, and 50% goes to the Independence Hall Preservation Fund for park improvements. SEC. 10. The Comptroller General can audit the Independence Hall Preservation Fund's expenditure records. SEC. 11. Coins issued under this Act are subject to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. Financial assurances are required. SEC. 12. Financial assurances are required to ensure no net cost to the government for issuing coins authorized by this Act. Payment, security, or guarantees are necessary for issuance.
